column2: It was under a blue cap that I first saw the honest face of Joe Collins.
column3: It was under a blue cap that I first saw the honest face of Joe Collins.

column2: In the third year of the late war a Maine regiment was passing through Boston, on its way to Washington.
column3: In the third year of the late war a Maine regiment was passing through Boston, on its way to Washington.

column2: The Common was all alive with troops and the spectators who clustered round them to say God-speed, as the brave fellows marched away to meet danger and death for our sakes.
column3: The Common was all alive with troops and the spectators who clustered round them to say God speed, as the brave fellows marched away to meet danger and death for our sakes.

column2: Every one was eager to do something; and, as the men stood at ease, the people mingled freely with them, offering gifts, hearty grips of the hand, and hopeful prophecies of victory in the end.
column3: Every one was eager to do something; and, as the men stood at ease, the people mingled freely with them, offering gifts, hearty grips of the hand, and hopeful prophecies of victory in the end.

column2: Irresistibly attracted, my boy Tom and I drew near, and soon, becoming excited by the scene, ravaged the fruit-stands in our neighborhood for tokens of our regard, mingling candy and congratulations, peanuts and prayers, apples and applause, in one enthusiastic jumble.
column3: Irresistibly attracted, my boy Tom and I drew near, and soon, becoming excited by the scene, ravaged the fruit stands in our neighborhood for tokens of our regard, mingling candy and congratulations, peanuts and prayers, apples and applause, in one enthusiastic jumble.

column2: While Tom was off on his third raid, my attention was attracted by a man who stood a little apart, looking as if his thoughts were far away.
column3: While Tom was off on his third raid, my attention was attracted by a man who stood a little apart, looking as if his thoughts were far away.

column2: All the men were fine, stalwart fellows, as Maine men usually are; but this one over-topped his comrades, standing straight and tall as a Norway pine, with a face full of the mingled shrewdness, sobriety, and self-possession of the typical New Englander.
column3: All the men were fine, stalwart fellows, as Maine men usually are; but this one over topped his comrades, standing straight and tall as a Norway pine, with a face full of the mingled shrewdness, sobriety, and self possession of the typical New Englander.

column2: I liked the look of him; and, seeing that he seemed solitary, even in a crowd, I offered him my last apple with a word of interest.
column3: I liked the look of him; and, seeing that he seemed solitary, even in a crowd, I offered him my last apple with a word of interest.

column2: The keen blue eyes met mine gratefully, and the apple began to vanish in vigorous bites as we talked; for no one thought of ceremony at such a time.
column3: The keen blue eyes met mine gratefully, and the apple began to vanish in vigorous bites as we talked; for no one thought of ceremony at such a time.

column2: Where are you from?
column3: Where are you from?

column2: Woolidge, ma'am.
column3: Woolidge, ma'am.

column2: Are you glad to go?
column3: Are you glad to go?

column2: Wal, there's two sides to that question.	Wal, there's two sides to that question.

column2: I calk'late to do my duty, and do it hearty: but it _is_ rough on a feller leavin' his folks, for good, maybe."
column3: I calk'late to do my duty, and do it hearty: but it underscore is underscore rough on a feller leavin' his folks, for good, maybe."

column2: There was a sudden huskiness in the man's voice that was not apple-skins, though he tried to make believe that it was.
column3: There was a sudden huskiness in the man's voice that was not apple skins, though he tried to make believe that it was.

column2: I knew a word about home would comfort him, so I went on with my questions.
column3: I knew a word about home would comfort him, so I went on with my questions.

column2: It is very hard.	It is very hard.

column2: Do you leave a family?"
column3: Do you leave a family?"

column2: My old mother, a sick brother,--and Lucindy.
column3: My old mother, a sick brother,--and Lucindy.

column2: The last word was uttered in a tone of intense regret, and his brown cheek reddened as he added hastily, to hide some embarrassment.--
column3: The last word was uttered in a tone of intense regret, and his brown cheek reddened as he added hastily, to hide some embarrassment.--

column2: You see, Jim went last year, and got pretty well used up; so I felt as if I'd ought to take my turn now.	You see, Jim went last year, and got pretty well used up; so I felt as if I'd ought to take my turn now.
column3: true

column2: Mother was a regular old hero about it and I dropped everything, and come off.
column3: Mother was a regular old hero about it and I dropped everything, and come off.

column2: Lucindy didn't think it was my duty; and that made it awful hard, I tell you."
column3: Lucindy didn't think it was my duty; and that made it awful hard, I tell you."

column2: Wives are less patriotic than mothers, I began; but he would not hear Lucindy blamed, and said quickly,--
column3: Wives are less patriotic than mothers, I began; but he would not hear Lucindy blamed, and said quickly,--

column2: She ain't my wife yet, but we calk'lated to be married in a month or so; and it was wus for her than for me, women lot so on not being disappointed.	She ain't my wife yet, but we calk'lated to be married in a month or so; and it was wus for her than for me, women lot so on not being disappointed.

column2: I _couldn't_ shirk, and here I be.

column2: When I git to work, I shall be all right: the first wrench is the tryin' part."
column3: When I git to work, I shall be all right: the first wrench is the tryin' part."

column2: Here he straightened his broad shoulders, and turned his face toward the flags fluttering far in front, as if no backward look should betray the longing of his heart for mother, home, and wife.
column3: Here he straightened his broad shoulders, and turned his face toward the flags fluttering far in front, as if no backward look should betray the longing of his heart for mother, home, and wife.

column2: I liked that little glimpse of character; and when Tom returned with empty hands, reporting that every stall was exhausted, I told him to find out what the man would like best, then run across the street and get it.
column3: I liked that little glimpse of character; and when Tom returned with empty hands, reporting that every stall was exhausted, I told him to find out what the man would like best, then run across the street and get it.

column2: Give us your purse, and I'll make him as happy as a king," said the boy, laughing, as he looked up admiringly at our tall friend, who looked down on him with an elder-brotherly air pleasant to see.
column3: Give us your purse, and I'll make him as happy as a king," said the boy, laughing, as he looked up admiringly at our tall friend, who looked down on him with an elder brotherly air pleasant to see.

column2: While Tom was gone, I found out Joe's name and business, promised to write and tell his mother how finely the regiment went off, and was just expressing a hope that we might meet again, for I too was going to the war as nurse, when the order to "Fall in!" came rolling down the ranks, and the talk was over.
column3: While Tom was gone, I found out Joe's name and business, promised to write and tell his mother how finely the regiment went off, and was just expressing a hope that we might meet again, for I too was going to the war as nurse, when the order to "Fall in!" came rolling down the ranks, and the talk was over.

column2: Fearing Tom would miss our man in the confusion, I kept my eye on him till the boy came rushing up with a packet of tobacco in one hand and a good supply of cigars in the other.
column3: Fearing Tom would miss our man in the confusion, I kept my eye on him till the boy came rushing up with a packet of tobacco in one hand and a good supply of cigars in the other.

column2: Not a romantic offering, certainly, but a very acceptable one, as Joe's face proved, as we scrambled these treasures into his pockets, all laughing at the flurry, while less fortunate comrades helped us, with an eye to a share of these fragrant luxuries by and by.
column3: Not a romantic offering, certainly, but a very acceptable one, as Joe's face proved, as we scrambled these treasures into his pockets, all laughing at the flurry, while less fortunate comrades helped us, with an eye to a share of these fragrant luxuries by and by.

column2: There was just time for this, a hearty shake of the big hand, and a grateful "Good-by, ma'am;" then the word was given, and they were off.
column3: There was just time for this, a hearty shake of the big hand, and a grateful "Good by, ma'am;" then the word was given, and they were off.

column2: Bent on seeing the last of them, Tom and I took a short cut, and came out on the wide street down which so many troops marched that year; and, mounting some high steps, we watched for our man, as we already called him.
column3: Bent on seeing the last of them, Tom and I took a short cut, and came out on the wide street down which so many troops marched that year; and, mounting some high steps, we watched for our man, as we already called him.

column2: As the inspiring music, the grand tramp, drew near, the old thrill went through the crowd, the old cheer broke out.
column3: As the inspiring music, the grand tramp, drew near, the old thrill went through the crowd, the old cheer broke out.

column2: But it was a different scene now than in the first enthusiastic, hopeful days. Young men and ardent boys filled the ranks then, brave by instinct, burning with loyal zeal, and blissfully unconscious of all that lay before them.
column3: But it was a different scene now than in the first enthusiastic, hopeful days. Young men and ardent boys filled the ranks then, brave by instinct, burning with loyal zeal, and blissfully unconscious of all that lay before them.

column2: Now the blue coats were worn by mature men, some gray, all grave and resolute: husbands and fathers, with the memory of wives and children tugging at their heart-strings; homes left desolate behind them, and before them the grim certainty of danger, hardship, and perhaps the lifelong helplessness worse than death.
column3: Now the blue coats were worn by mature men, some gray, all grave and resolute: husbands and fathers, with the memory of wives and children tugging at their heart strings; homes left desolate behind them, and before them the grim certainty of danger, hardship, and perhaps the lifelong helplessness worse than death.

column2: Little of the glamour of romance about the war now: they saw it as it was, a long, hard task; and here were the men to do it well.
column3: Little of the glamour of romance about the war now: they saw it as it was, a long, hard task; and here were the men to do it well.

column2: Even the lookers-on were different now.
column3: Even the lookers on were different now.

column2: Once all was wild enthusiasm and glad uproar; now men's lips were set, and women's smileless as they cheered; fewer handkerchiefs whitened the air, for wet eyes needed them; and sudden lulls, almost solemn in their stillness, followed the acclamations of the crowd.
column3: Once all was wild enthusiasm and glad uproar; now men's lips were set, and women's smileless as they cheered; fewer handkerchiefs whitened the air, for wet eyes needed them; and sudden lulls, almost solemn in their stillness, followed the acclamations of the crowd.

column2: All watched with quickened breath and brave souls that living wave, blue below, and bright with a steely glitter above, as it flowed down the street and away to distant battle-fields already stained with precious blood.
column3: All watched with quickened breath and brave souls that living wave, blue below, and bright with a steely glitter above, as it flowed down the street and away to distant battle fields already stained with precious blood.

column2: There he is!	There he is!

column2: The outside man, and tallest of the lot.
column3: The outside man, and tallest of the lot.

column2: Give him a cheer, auntie: he sees us, and remembers!" cried Tom, nearly tumbling off his perch, as he waved his hat, and pointed out Joe Collins.
column3: Give him a cheer, auntie: he sees us, and remembers!" cried Tom, nearly tumbling off his perch, as he waved his hat, and pointed out Joe Collins.

column2: Yes, there he was, looking up, with a smile on his brave brown face, my little nosegay in his button-hole, a suspicious bulge in the pocket close by, and doubtless a comfortable quid in his mouth, to cheer the weary march.
column3: Yes, there he was, looking up, with a smile on his brave brown face, my little nosegay in his button hole, a suspicious bulge in the pocket close by, and doubtless a comfortable quid in his mouth, to cheer the weary march.

column2: How like an old friend he looked, though we had only met fifteen minutes ago; how glad we were to be there to smile back at him, and send him on his way feeling that, even in a strange city, there was some one to say, "God bless you, Joe!" We watched the tallest blue cap till it vanished, and then went home in a glow of patriotism,--Tom to long for his turn to come, I to sew vigorously on the gray gown the new nurse burned to wear as soon as possible, and both of us to think and speak often of poor Joe Collins and his Lucindy.
column3: How like an old friend he looked, though we had only met fifteen minutes ago; how glad we were to be there to smile back at him, and send him on his way feeling that, even in a strange city, there was some one to say, "God bless you, Joe!" We watched the tallest blue cap till it vanished, and then went home in a glow of patriotism,--Tom to long for his turn to come, I to sew vigorously on the gray gown the new nurse burned to wear as soon as possible, and both of us to think and speak often of poor Joe Collins and his Lucindy.

column2: All this happened long ago; but it is well to recall those stirring times,--to keep fresh the memory of sacrifices made for us by men like these; to see to it that the debt we owe them is honestly, gladly paid; and, while we decorate the graves of those who died, to remember also those who still live to deserve our grateful care.
column3: All this happened long ago; but it is well to recall those stirring times,--to keep fresh the memory of sacrifices made for us by men like these; to see to it that the debt we owe them is honestly, gladly paid; and, while we decorate the graves of those who died, to remember also those who still live to deserve our grateful care.
